The lecture preceding Dr. Gunewardine's was delivered by His
Excellency, Dr. Farid Zeinddine,
Ambassador from Syria, on
"Syria's Arab and International
Relations".
Dr. Zeinddine, an international
lawyer, has been prominent in the
Arab national movement for independence and unity, and was one
of the authors of the Syrian constitution. After Syria gained her
Independence in 1943, he was ap
pointed ambassador to Russia, and
for the past ten years, he has led
the Syrian delegation to the UN.

ST. PAUL CLEANERS

JHU Students Attend Lectures
During Religion-In -Life Week
Religion-in-Life W e e k, Feb.
16th-20th, brought to the Johns
Hopkins University many prominent American religious leaders
to address students interested in
finding answers to the questions
which various religions pose.
Nine groups which compose the
Council of Religious Groups
at the Hopkins organized under
the leadership of Dr. Chester L.
Wickwire, Executive Secretary of
the Johns Hopkins YMCA, participated in sponsoring these speakers. They are the Baptist Students
Union, the Canterbury Association,
the Christian Science Organization, the Jewish Students' Association, the Lutheran Students' Association, the Newman Club, the
Wesley Foundation, the Westrnin-

Ster Fellowship, and the Johns
Hopkins YMCA.
The main speaker was Will Herberg, whose talks caused several
students to ask for private interviews. A question and answer
session at the end of his speech
brought a large response by the
audience. He emphasized the importance of individual decision in
religion.
The following committees, listed
with their co-chairmen, were instrumental in the carrying out of
the program: Committee on Organization, Bill Strutton and Lew
Pusch; Committee of Arrange-

What Price Accreditation?
The current controversy about accreditation of the School of
Engineering goes far deeper than whether or not the school is
accredited. The position of the colleges and universities in the
field of engineering is at issue.
The old, traditional view is that engineers receive virtually
their entire education in some specialized field of engineering at
the college which they attended before finding a job. This involves
taking many specialized, technological courses that are of little
use outside of a narrow field and which, in college, leave little time
for general liberal arts courses.
The new approach, adopted by Hopkins in 1949, contends that
the engineer seldom works in the field in which he is trained
and there is no reason to teach him a lot of specialized technology
in college. Therefore, Hopkins' School of Engineering teaches
the basic fundamentals of science and engineering and leaves the
technological details for the student to learn on the job.
The Hopkins viewpoint has been supported almost unanimously by the large employers of engineers. The educational institutions have not, however, responded to this approach with the
same amount of enthusiasm. Because accrediting, teams are composed mostly of professors from other institutions, Hopkins has
found its accreditation affected by the controversy.
The practical effect of lack of accreditation would be an increase of four years in the time required to get a professional
engineering license for Hopkins graduates. Professional licenses
have not been significant in the past, although their significance is
apparently increasing now, and will probably continue to do so.
We do not feel that this is particularly important because all but
two of the Hopkins departments are still accredited and in the next
two years the situation may be sufficiently clarified to warrant
re-acceditation. However, all prospective engineering students
should be made fully aware of the situation before they come to
Hopkins.
The near unanimous support of government and industry,
which would be most sensitive to any defects in engineering education, seems to indicate that Hopkins is on the right track.
Although the new concept of engineering education did not
originate exclusively here, Hopkins has been one of the first to
put it into practice. Various pressures have been put on the University in the form of criticism and threatened withdrawal of
state funds, but the faculty has stood firm in its decision to modify
the engineering curriculum.
This has been consistent with the history of the University.
The original University represented a radical departure from
traditional American colleges, and the School of Medicine similarly revolutionized medical education. The original faculty survived
early opposition and lived to see most U.S. medical schools pattern
themselves after Hopkins and many of the Hopkins innovations
adopted in general higher education in America. We hope that
the School of Engineering will be able to do the same.

To the Editor:
As president of one of the SAC
organizations on this campus, the
Glee Club, I have in the past been
asked to or have asked to put
some information in the News-Letter concerning our activities. I
would not be writing this letter
if this information had been printed when it should have been. But
on at least two occasions • this
hasn't been done.
Back in November, I was asked
for a story on the Glee Club concerning its Christmas activities. I
gave your reporter a story, and I
looked for it in the following issue,
but it did not appear. The reason?
Someone mislaid it. So the following wetfk another of your reporters came to me for the same
story. Again it was lost. Finally,
on your third try, you finally
managed to get it printed.
Last week I was again asked for
a story, to appear in your gala,
sixteen page issue. But, according
to the reporter who got the story
from me, there wasn't enough
space left in the paper. (This reporter, incidentally, was one of
the two who didn't get their stoi ies
printed last November.) This
ordinarily wouldn't bother me
much, but for two reasons. First,
I considered the information I
gave important in that it concerned
an event approaching on March 19
of interest to the socially-minded
segment of the student body (however small that segment may be),
that is, the Interfraternity Sing
and the party following, which is
open to the whole school. Secondly,
some of the articles that were
printed (and apparently considered
more important) were of little importance to the greater portion of
the student body, or else could have
waited another week or so. But instead you elected to fill your sixteen pages with many lines of drab
matter interesting only to a small
portion of the liberal arts students. Remember, there are also engineers, pre-meds and other groups
in attendance at the Hopkins. Also,
I believe, along with many others
who have learned something of
your methods of getting an issue
together, that with an efficient
organization things such as I have
mentioned in this letter might not
have happened.
Until something is done to improve the methods and management of your. paper, it will remain,
in the eyes Of many of us, no better than Mr. Scott's leading paper
that y9,u so vehemently attacked
last year.
JOHN P. DEFANDORF
P.S. Any opinions expressed in
this letter are my own and do not
necessarily reflect the thoughts of
the other Glee Club members, although I know a large number of
them share my views.

Pro Musica
The recent drops in record prices
bring to mind the explanation of
a top executive in a large record
company, who, when asked -how
his company could manage to make
money at the new much lower
prices, replied, "Well, we are losing twenty cents on every record
we sell but we hope to make it up
on the volume."
The average consumer need not
worry himself with the complications of the industry's finances.
He is now in a better position to
obtain more and better records for
less money than at any time in the
past.
And while prices have dropped,
even more important, quality has
improved. The best example of
improved quality may be shown in
the new Remington releases. One
of these releases features Jorge
Bolet, with Thor Johnson conducting the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra in a brilliant performance
of the 2nd Piano Concerto by
Prokofiev. (Rem. 199-182). Bolet
has a broad, rather percussive
technique, perfectly suited for the
work, which is at times a bit noisy
but generally of great interest to
admirers of Prokofiev and in fact,
to anyone willing to associate himself with the more serious compositions of the twentieth century.
Thoroughly Russian
The work was written while
Prokofiev was still studying in
the St. Petersburg Conservatory,
yet it reflects quite a remarkable
degree of maturity, and contains
several melodies, thoroughly Russian and thoroughly beautiful,
which Prokofiev never surpassed.
Most surprising of all is Remington's new manufacturing process
which offers the consumer a pure
vinyl pressing of top quality (with
low surface noise), factory sealed
in a plastic sleeve. The orchestral
sound, particularly that of the
brasses, is truly exceptional. In
addition to its musical and technical qualities, this record, along
with all other Remington 12" releases, sells for $2.99, a full dollar less than the big name Lp's.
Regardless of the mediocre reviews in Baltimore, given these
works, Remington also offers several recordings conducted by Jonel
Perlea, of quite exceptional merit.
Debussy's La Boite a Joujoux,
(The Box of Toys) is a charming
little piece, full of good humor
and sophisticated witticisms. The
work reminds one of Jacques
lbert's Divertissement, but is generally better written. One wishes
only for a slightly greater continuity between the numerous movements of the work. Again, the
recorded sound is good.
The over-played and ever-popu-

lar 1st Piano Concerto by Liszt,
(Rem. 199-166), is also available
on this label, with the pianist Edward Kilenyi and the RIAS orchestra of Berlin conducted by
Perlea. This performance of the
concerto is probably the second
best recording Kilenyi has made.
However, it pales in contrast to
the exciting Todtentanz, also by
Liszt, which is on the back of the
record. This reviewer, upon overcoming his prejudice against Liszt,
found the work extremely exciting, a virtuoso's dream, yet really
beautifully written. Based on the
Dies Irae, the work shows off
Liszt's sometimes dubious compositorial abilities to best advantage. Liszt gives us a bit of
Bach, a bit of Mendelssohn, and a
lot of Liszt, for all of which we
are grateful.
Gaite Parisienne
Finally, this reviewer was confronted by three recordings of Offenbach's Gaite Parisienne. Victor
offers Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops (LM-1817; $3.98) in a
"New Orthophonic" recording to
replace Fiedler's older but still
popular performance. Columbia offers Eugene Ormandy and the
Philadelphia Orchestra in a second
performance (3ML-4895; $3.98);
and Remington offers Manuel Rosenthal and the RIAS Orchestra
of Berlin (199-172) in a third.
Ormandy's engineers have done
him well and the sound fairly
bristles in the grooves. However
the "great man with the great
orchestra" seems to be out of his
medium in this light music. His
tempos seem a bit strict and unyielding, and often rushed,
On the other hand, this is Fiedler's music, and his performance
is tops. Victor's sound is harsher
than Columbia's, with greater
emphasis on cymbal crashes and
percussion than Columbia offers.
Also, Victor's pressings of this
record are for some reason, filled
with "blips", small groove separations about an inch long, concentrated on one side of the record.
Most of the pressings noted had
them, some don't. Watch out!
Remington Good
Remington's version of the work
stands the comparison well. The
sound is fine, not as bright as
either the Columbia or the Victor,
but better balanced than the Victor. Rosenthal, who orchestrated
the work, conducts it as if it were
an old friend (which it undoubtedly must be) and his orchestra
keeps pace with him nicely. This
is another good example of Remington's attempted ascendancy to
equal status in the recording
world.
R.K.

Fifis Beat Rowland Ruland ChampIn M-D Tourneyi
In B-Ball Playoffs
Matmen Drop To Fourth Place Si
JHU Riflers Face
Penn State's Lions
Riding high on the crest of a
two-game winning streak compiled
over last weekend, the Blue Jay
rifle team plays host to Penn
State Lions tomorrow at Homewood.
Despite the fact that the team
lost to State in a postal match
earlier in the season, Coach Sgt.
Charles Brown is confident of
victory. "In a postal match," says
Brown, "the teams shoot separately on their own territory, and just
mail their scores to various
schools. When the boys are shooting shoulder to shoulder away
from home, they don't figure to
do as well. Also, our team has been
improving constantly; and we figure to keep up the improvement."
Over the weekend, the team defeated Loyola on Friday night, and
George Washington on Saturday.
The final score against Loyola was
1353 to 1266. The top Jays shooter against the Greyhounds was
Roger Van Riper with a 281.
In the match against George
Washington, which the Jays took
1350 to 1337, top Hopkins shooter
Was Bud Skrivan with a 279.
The two victories over the weekend boosted the Jays record to a
5-3 mark.

BASKETBALL
Phi Gam beat the Rowland
Ghosts, 41-36, in the school championship, which is played by the
winners of the fraternity and independent leagues.
Ted Graser led the winners with
12 points. Close behind him were
Gene Joyce and Barrie Wood. Jim
Travis spearheaded the losers with
15 points.
BOWLING
The Goofballs, for the third
straight year, won the independent
bowling championship. Going into
the last day, three teams—Sig Ep,
the Flunking "5", and the Goofballs—were all tied for first place.
The Goofballs won all three ,of
their games against the Flunking
"5,", and Sig Ep had beaten the
Alley Cats with ease in the first
two games. But the Alley Cat captain, Dick Bambach, ruined Sig
Ep's championship chances when
he barely grazed his remaining pin
for a box in the last frame.
Tomorrow, at 12:30 p.m., at the
Stadium Bowling Center, the fraternities will roll for Wittich
Trophy points. AEPi will be protecting its 1954 championship.
PING PONG
Ronald Creamer and Willie Prochazka won the YMCA ping-pong
doubles tourney by beating Ira
Anderson and Huston Hemphill,
21-18, 29-27, and 21-19.

Jay Foilers Prepare
To Defend 111-A Title
In their last mach before defending their Middle Atlantic
championships, the Hopkins fencers traveled to Pennsylvania
where they defeated a strong
Haverford team, 14-13, last Saturday.
The home team offered stiff opposition to the Blue Jays, and the
match wasn't decided until the last
touch of the last bout.
The biggest point-getting squad
for the Jays was the foil team,
which topped the home team, 6-3,
as Captain Bill Strutton and Gerry
Fenichel each captured three
matches. The up-and-coming Blue
Jay sabre team also topped the
Pennsylvanians, as they won 5-4
on the strength of three victories
by John Forte, and single tallies
by Darrell Carter and Dick Heckman. The usually strong epee
team was upended by .the Pennsylvanians 6-3.• In the last bout
of the day, Dick Oles, who won
all three of his matches, scored the
last touch and won his bout, 3-2,
thereby giving the Hopkins men
a 14-13 victory.
The match with Haverford
closed out the regular schedule for
the Jays, whose only remaining
activity is the Middle Atlantic
Championships, which are to be
held at the Hopkins gym on
March 12.
The Jays fenced a tough schedule this season, opening with the
always - tough Midshipmen from
Annapolis, .who .defeated them
21-6 .The next match for the
Jays of Cal Schlick was with the
Big Ten Champions from Champaign, the University of Illinois.
The fighting Illini stopped the
Blue Jays, 16-11, in a tight match.
The third match of the season was
with the Quakers of the University of Pennsylvania. The Red and
Blue are one of the top teams in
the country, and they showed

their power as they subdued the
Schlickmen, 17-10.
After the first three defeats the
Jays bounded back with victories
over two Middle Atlantic opponents, Temple and Haverford.
These two teams will be at the Hopkins gym, a week from Saturday
when they will be trying to defeat
the champion Jays in the Middle
Atlantic Championship Tournament.
Top winners for the Jays this
season were Captain Bill Strutton
who won eight out of twelve bouts,
and Gerry Fenichel, who copped
eight out of 15. Next in line with
victories are Hugh Montague, Middle Atlantic epee champion, who
won seven out of 12, and John
Forte, and Dick Oles, who won
seven out of 15.
Coach Cal Schlick believes that
with a little more pre-season practice the Jays would have been able
to pull some upsets, especially
against Illinois. Cal has also noted
with pride that some of his boys
have improved tremendously, Cal
singled out Darrell Carter and Kim
Traub as the two most improved.
As far as prospects for next
year are concerned, graduation will
take Strutton, Fenichel, Vic Marder, Oles, Hugh Montague, and
Pat Pironti.. However, the Jays
will have a strong nucleus to build
with, as John Forte, Darrell Carter,
Kim Traub, Dick Heckman, Sal
Gengaro, and Dick Everett are
returning. Also on the squad next
year will be Al Rose, one time
Maryland Open Champion, who,
this year, helped Cal by coaching
the Blue Jay Freshmen.
Coming up from the ranks of
the freshman team will be the entire epee squad of Tom Feher, Bill
Hull, and Joe Rivkin, and the entire foil squad; Fred Rosenbloom,
Howard Pierce, and John Zung.
Also coming up will be sabre man
TornFetsch.

Frosh Grapplers
Win Final Set-To
Rounding out the season with
an informal meet with Gettysburg,
February 24 at Gettysburg, the
Freshman wrestling team showed
considerable improvement since
the first meet of the season with
Delaware and benefited greatly
from the work with the Gettysburg
boys, according to Freshman Mentor Bob Scott.
In the final meet of the season,
the Jays competed with a mixed
jayvee and freshman team, some
members of which had seen previous varsity experience at Gettysburg and several frosh who could
beat their varsity opponents.
The most pleasing performance
of the evening was turned in by
JHU's 127-pounder, Dean Bangor,
who pinned his man in the second
period of his match. Wrestling for
only the second time of his career,
Bangor moved well and showed
considerable drive and determination.
Co-captain Bob Partridge went
down to defeat in a close 5-4 decision in the 137-pound bout. Partridge, who was leading several
times during the match, finished
with the score even, 4-4, but lost
on riding time. The other co-captain, Mike McLoughlin, wrestling
in the 147-pound division, put up
a game fight before being pinned
in his scrimmage.
Others who lost by decision were
heavyweight Mark Kramer and
157-pounder, Bob Dorfman. Dorfman put up a tremendously game
battle in losing to an opponent who
numerous times had him in a
pinning combination. However,
Dorfman's determination kept him
from being pinned by his experienced opponent. In other matches,
both Dave Hochberg and Jim Lory
were pinned in the initial bouts of
their short careers.

What Price Accreditation?
The current controversy about accreditation of the School of
Engineering goes far deeper than whether or not the school is
accredited. The position of the colleges and universities in the
field of engineering is at issue.
The old, traditional view is that engineers receive virtually
their entire education in some specialized field of engineering at
the college which they attended before finding a job. This involves
taking many specialized, technological courses that are of little
use outside of a narrow field and which, in college, leave little time
for general liberal arts courses.
The new approach, adopted by Hopkins in 1949, contends that
the engineer seldom works in the field in which he is trained
and there is no reason to teach him a lot of specialized technology
in college. Therefore, Hopkins' School of Engineering teaches
the basic fundamentals of science and engineering and leaves the
technological details for the student to learn on the job.
The Hopkins viewpoint has been supported almost unanimously by the large employers of engineers. The educational institutions have not, however, responded to this approach with the
same amount of enthusiasm. Because accrediting, teams are composed mostly of professors from other institutions, Hopkins has
found its accreditation affected by the controversy.
The practical effect of lack of accreditation would be an increase of four years in the time required to get a professional
engineering license for Hopkins graduates. Professional licenses
have not been significant in the past, although their significance is
apparently increasing now, and will probably continue to do so.
We do not feel that this is particularly important because all but
two of the Hopkins departments are still accredited and in the next
two years the situation may be sufficiently clarified to warrant
re-acceditation. However, all prospective engineering students
should be made fully aware of the situation before they come to
Hopkins.
The near unanimous support of government and industry,
which would be most sensitive to any defects in engineering education, seems to indicate that Hopkins is on the right track.
Although the new concept of engineering education did not
originate exclusively here, Hopkins has been one of the first to
put it into practice. Various pressures have been put on the University in the form of criticism and threatened withdrawal of
state funds, but the faculty has stood firm in its decision to modify
the engineering curriculum.
This has been consistent with the history of the University.
The original University represented a radical departure from
traditional American colleges, and the School of Medicine similarly revolutionized medical education. The original faculty survived
early opposition and lived to see most U.S. medical schools pattern
themselves after Hopkins and many of the Hopkins innovations
adopted in general higher education in America. We hope that
the School of Engineering will be able to do the same.

To the Editor:
As president of one of the SAC
organizations on this campus, the
Glee Club, I have in the past been
asked to or have asked to put
some information in the News-Letter concerning our activities. I
would not be writing this letter
if this information had been printed when it should have been. But
on at least two occasions • this
hasn't been done.
Back in November, I was asked
for a story on the Glee Club concerning its Christmas activities. I
gave your reporter a story, and I
looked for it in the following issue,
but it did not appear. The reason?
Someone mislaid it. So the following wetfk another of your reporters came to me for the same
story. Again it was lost. Finally,
on your third try, you finally
managed to get it printed.
Last week I was again asked for
a story, to appear in your gala,
sixteen page issue. But, according
to the reporter who got the story
from me, there wasn't enough
space left in the paper. (This reporter, incidentally, was one of
the two who didn't get their stoi ies
printed last November.) This
ordinarily wouldn't bother me
much, but for two reasons. First,
I considered the information I
gave important in that it concerned
an event approaching on March 19
of interest to the socially-minded
segment of the student body (however small that segment may be),
that is, the Interfraternity Sing
and the party following, which is
open to the whole school. Secondly,
some of the articles that were
printed (and apparently considered
more important) were of little importance to the greater portion of
the student body, or else could have
waited another week or so. But instead you elected to fill your sixteen pages with many lines of drab
matter interesting only to a small
portion of the liberal arts students. Remember, there are also engineers, pre-meds and other groups
in attendance at the Hopkins. Also,
I believe, along with many others
who have learned something of
your methods of getting an issue
together, that with an efficient
organization things such as I have
mentioned in this letter might not
have happened.
Until something is done to improve the methods and management of your. paper, it will remain,
in the eyes Of many of us, no better than Mr. Scott's leading paper
that y9,u so vehemently attacked
last year.
JOHN P. DEFANDORF
P.S. Any opinions expressed in
this letter are my own and do not
necessarily reflect the thoughts of
the other Glee Club members, although I know a large number of
them share my views.

Pro Musica
The recent drops in record prices
bring to mind the explanation of
a top executive in a large record
company, who, when asked -how
his company could manage to make
money at the new much lower
prices, replied, "Well, we are losing twenty cents on every record
we sell but we hope to make it up
on the volume."
The average consumer need not
worry himself with the complications of the industry's finances.
He is now in a better position to
obtain more and better records for
less money than at any time in the
past.
And while prices have dropped,
even more important, quality has
improved. The best example of
improved quality may be shown in
the new Remington releases. One
of these releases features Jorge
Bolet, with Thor Johnson conducting the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra in a brilliant performance
of the 2nd Piano Concerto by
Prokofiev. (Rem. 199-182). Bolet
has a broad, rather percussive
technique, perfectly suited for the
work, which is at times a bit noisy
but generally of great interest to
admirers of Prokofiev and in fact,
to anyone willing to associate himself with the more serious compositions of the twentieth century.
Thoroughly Russian
The work was written while
Prokofiev was still studying in
the St. Petersburg Conservatory,
yet it reflects quite a remarkable
degree of maturity, and contains
several melodies, thoroughly Russian and thoroughly beautiful,
which Prokofiev never surpassed.
Most surprising of all is Remington's new manufacturing process
which offers the consumer a pure
vinyl pressing of top quality (with
low surface noise), factory sealed
in a plastic sleeve. The orchestral
sound, particularly that of the
brasses, is truly exceptional. In
addition to its musical and technical qualities, this record, along
with all other Remington 12" releases, sells for $2.99, a full dollar less than the big name Lp's.
Regardless of the mediocre reviews in Baltimore, given these
works, Remington also offers several recordings conducted by Jonel
Perlea, of quite exceptional merit.
Debussy's La Boite a Joujoux,
(The Box of Toys) is a charming
little piece, full of good humor
and sophisticated witticisms. The
work reminds one of Jacques
lbert's Divertissement, but is generally better written. One wishes
only for a slightly greater continuity between the numerous movements of the work. Again, the
recorded sound is good.
The over-played and ever-popu-

lar 1st Piano Concerto by Liszt,
(Rem. 199-166), is also available
on this label, with the pianist Edward Kilenyi and the RIAS orchestra of Berlin conducted by
Perlea. This performance of the
concerto is probably the second
best recording Kilenyi has made.
However, it pales in contrast to
the exciting Todtentanz, also by
Liszt, which is on the back of the
record. This reviewer, upon overcoming his prejudice against Liszt,
found the work extremely exciting, a virtuoso's dream, yet really
beautifully written. Based on the
Dies Irae, the work shows off
Liszt's sometimes dubious compositorial abilities to best advantage. Liszt gives us a bit of
Bach, a bit of Mendelssohn, and a
lot of Liszt, for all of which we
are grateful.
Gaite Parisienne
Finally, this reviewer was confronted by three recordings of Offenbach's Gaite Parisienne. Victor
offers Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops (LM-1817; $3.98) in a
"New Orthophonic" recording to
replace Fiedler's older but still
popular performance. Columbia offers Eugene Ormandy and the
Philadelphia Orchestra in a second
performance (3ML-4895; $3.98);
and Remington offers Manuel Rosenthal and the RIAS Orchestra
of Berlin (199-172) in a third.
Ormandy's engineers have done
him well and the sound fairly
bristles in the grooves. However
the "great man with the great
orchestra" seems to be out of his
medium in this light music. His
tempos seem a bit strict and unyielding, and often rushed,
On the other hand, this is Fiedler's music, and his performance
is tops. Victor's sound is harsher
than Columbia's, with greater
emphasis on cymbal crashes and
percussion than Columbia offers.
Also, Victor's pressings of this
record are for some reason, filled
with "blips", small groove separations about an inch long, concentrated on one side of the record.
Most of the pressings noted had
them, some don't. Watch out!
Remington Good
Remington's version of the work
stands the comparison well. The
sound is fine, not as bright as
either the Columbia or the Victor,
but better balanced than the Victor. Rosenthal, who orchestrated
the work, conducts it as if it were
an old friend (which it undoubtedly must be) and his orchestra
keeps pace with him nicely. This
is another good example of Remington's attempted ascendancy to
equal status in the recording
world.
R.K.

Fifis Beat Rowland Ruland ChampIn M-D Tourneyi
In B-Ball Playoffs
Matmen Drop To Fourth Place Si
JHU Riflers Face
Penn State's Lions
Riding high on the crest of a
two-game winning streak compiled
over last weekend, the Blue Jay
rifle team plays host to Penn
State Lions tomorrow at Homewood.
Despite the fact that the team
lost to State in a postal match
earlier in the season, Coach Sgt.
Charles Brown is confident of
victory. "In a postal match," says
Brown, "the teams shoot separately on their own territory, and just
mail their scores to various
schools. When the boys are shooting shoulder to shoulder away
from home, they don't figure to
do as well. Also, our team has been
improving constantly; and we figure to keep up the improvement."
Over the weekend, the team defeated Loyola on Friday night, and
George Washington on Saturday.
The final score against Loyola was
1353 to 1266. The top Jays shooter against the Greyhounds was
Roger Van Riper with a 281.
In the match against George
Washington, which the Jays took
1350 to 1337, top Hopkins shooter
Was Bud Skrivan with a 279.
The two victories over the weekend boosted the Jays record to a
5-3 mark.

BASKETBALL
Phi Gam beat the Rowland
Ghosts, 41-36, in the school championship, which is played by the
winners of the fraternity and independent leagues.
Ted Graser led the winners with
12 points. Close behind him were
Gene Joyce and Barrie Wood. Jim
Travis spearheaded the losers with
15 points.
BOWLING
The Goofballs, for the third
straight year, won the independent
bowling championship. Going into
the last day, three teams—Sig Ep,
the Flunking "5", and the Goofballs—were all tied for first place.
The Goofballs won all three ,of
their games against the Flunking
"5,", and Sig Ep had beaten the
Alley Cats with ease in the first
two games. But the Alley Cat captain, Dick Bambach, ruined Sig
Ep's championship chances when
he barely grazed his remaining pin
for a box in the last frame.
Tomorrow, at 12:30 p.m., at the
Stadium Bowling Center, the fraternities will roll for Wittich
Trophy points. AEPi will be protecting its 1954 championship.
PING PONG
Ronald Creamer and Willie Prochazka won the YMCA ping-pong
doubles tourney by beating Ira
Anderson and Huston Hemphill,
21-18, 29-27, and 21-19.

Jay Foilers Prepare
To Defend 111-A Title
In their last mach before defending their Middle Atlantic
championships, the Hopkins fencers traveled to Pennsylvania
where they defeated a strong
Haverford team, 14-13, last Saturday.
The home team offered stiff opposition to the Blue Jays, and the
match wasn't decided until the last
touch of the last bout.
The biggest point-getting squad
for the Jays was the foil team,
which topped the home team, 6-3,
as Captain Bill Strutton and Gerry
Fenichel each captured three
matches. The up-and-coming Blue
Jay sabre team also topped the
Pennsylvanians, as they won 5-4
on the strength of three victories
by John Forte, and single tallies
by Darrell Carter and Dick Heckman. The usually strong epee
team was upended by .the Pennsylvanians 6-3.• In the last bout
of the day, Dick Oles, who won
all three of his matches, scored the
last touch and won his bout, 3-2,
thereby giving the Hopkins men
a 14-13 victory.
The match with Haverford
closed out the regular schedule for
the Jays, whose only remaining
activity is the Middle Atlantic
Championships, which are to be
held at the Hopkins gym on
March 12.
The Jays fenced a tough schedule this season, opening with the
always - tough Midshipmen from
Annapolis, .who .defeated them
21-6 .The next match for the
Jays of Cal Schlick was with the
Big Ten Champions from Champaign, the University of Illinois.
The fighting Illini stopped the
Blue Jays, 16-11, in a tight match.
The third match of the season was
with the Quakers of the University of Pennsylvania. The Red and
Blue are one of the top teams in
the country, and they showed

their power as they subdued the
Schlickmen, 17-10.
After the first three defeats the
Jays bounded back with victories
over two Middle Atlantic opponents, Temple and Haverford.
These two teams will be at the Hopkins gym, a week from Saturday
when they will be trying to defeat
the champion Jays in the Middle
Atlantic Championship Tournament.
Top winners for the Jays this
season were Captain Bill Strutton
who won eight out of twelve bouts,
and Gerry Fenichel, who copped
eight out of 15. Next in line with
victories are Hugh Montague, Middle Atlantic epee champion, who
won seven out of 12, and John
Forte, and Dick Oles, who won
seven out of 15.
Coach Cal Schlick believes that
with a little more pre-season practice the Jays would have been able
to pull some upsets, especially
against Illinois. Cal has also noted
with pride that some of his boys
have improved tremendously, Cal
singled out Darrell Carter and Kim
Traub as the two most improved.
As far as prospects for next
year are concerned, graduation will
take Strutton, Fenichel, Vic Marder, Oles, Hugh Montague, and
Pat Pironti.. However, the Jays
will have a strong nucleus to build
with, as John Forte, Darrell Carter,
Kim Traub, Dick Heckman, Sal
Gengaro, and Dick Everett are
returning. Also on the squad next
year will be Al Rose, one time
Maryland Open Champion, who,
this year, helped Cal by coaching
the Blue Jay Freshmen.
Coming up from the ranks of
the freshman team will be the entire epee squad of Tom Feher, Bill
Hull, and Joe Rivkin, and the entire foil squad; Fred Rosenbloom,
Howard Pierce, and John Zung.
Also coming up will be sabre man
TornFetsch.

Frosh Grapplers
Win Final Set-To
Rounding out the season with
an informal meet with Gettysburg,
February 24 at Gettysburg, the
Freshman wrestling team showed
considerable improvement since
the first meet of the season with
Delaware and benefited greatly
from the work with the Gettysburg
boys, according to Freshman Mentor Bob Scott.
In the final meet of the season,
the Jays competed with a mixed
jayvee and freshman team, some
members of which had seen previous varsity experience at Gettysburg and several frosh who could
beat their varsity opponents.
The most pleasing performance
of the evening was turned in by
JHU's 127-pounder, Dean Bangor,
who pinned his man in the second
period of his match. Wrestling for
only the second time of his career,
Bangor moved well and showed
considerable drive and determination.
Co-captain Bob Partridge went
down to defeat in a close 5-4 decision in the 137-pound bout. Partridge, who was leading several
times during the match, finished
with the score even, 4-4, but lost
on riding time. The other co-captain, Mike McLoughlin, wrestling
in the 147-pound division, put up
a game fight before being pinned
in his scrimmage.
Others who lost by decision were
heavyweight Mark Kramer and
157-pounder, Bob Dorfman. Dorfman put up a tremendously game
battle in losing to an opponent who
numerous times had him in a
pinning combination. However,
Dorfman's determination kept him
from being pinned by his experienced opponent. In other matches,
both Dave Hochberg and Jim Lory
were pinned in the initial bouts of
their short careers.
